column4: one gotcha to watch out for is that ifconfig and the shortcuts ifup/ifdown use different state files, so if you take an interface down with ifdown and then back up with ifconfig, then ifdown won't work because it iwll think the interface is already down.
it becomes /dev/video
Don't see it there.  This is a standard digital still camera, canon powershot a520.
ah....those should mount as usb drives
have you turned on the camera?
yeah, it's on and it's in playback mode.
mount should show if it is mounted
mount shows a lot of stuff, but none of it jumps out at me as the camera...
it would show as /dev/sdb or sdc
if you are in gnome it should have put an icon on the desktop for the 'drive'
http://pastebin.ubuntu.com/212309/
it appears ubuntu is seeing the camera being plugged in, but not recognizing it as a camera and not mounting it as a drive
what kind of camera?
Nothing on my desktop;  when I look at it in nautilus it's there and it shows me some folders and a message about "This folder contains digital media" and a button to open f-spot.
ok....then nautilus is seeing it. can you open f-spot and see your pictures?
Okay, so I just turned it off and back on, and this time, since i'd installed gthumb, the popup offered to let me open it in gthumb as well as f-spot.
No, when I open f-spot I only see my old pictures.
When I open with gthumb, I get this erropr:

Unable to mount Canon, Inc. Digital IXUS 50 (normal mode) / IXY Digital 55 (normal mode) / Powershot A520 (PTP mode) / Powershot SD400 (normal mode) and then in smaller type below it, "Error initializing camera: -60: Could not lock the device."
It's the A520, btw.
found this in a google search http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=250328
Argh... that really, really, really sucks.  Thanks
also found an item that says they can access the camera using gtkam, but that is old info
try, in a terminal, gphoto2 --auto-detect
